introduction.body:
This section explores your business's viability, financial management and cash flow planning.

Have you ever been in a situation where your sales are up, yet your profit is down? Assess your current financial situation and find out where there may be opportunities for growth and improvement.

questions.label: Do you have a budget for the next 12 months?
questions.helpText: A budget helps you plan for what your business will spend and earn over the next year. It includes things like: Regular expenses, Future costs you expect, How much money you think you'll make.

positiveMessage.title: Budget in Place!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You have planned ahead with a budget to guide your business over the next year.

recommendation.title: Create a Budget
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Learn how to build a budget to help you keep your business financially healthy. A budget shows what you expect to earn and spend, and helps you plan for things like stock, wages, and marketing. It also helps you set money aside for important activities and make sure your business stays profitable and on track.

Learn about creating a budget.

questions.label: Do you know what it costs to run your business?
questions.helpText: Running a business comes with different types of costs, like: Fixed costs - things you pay regularly, like rent, licences, or permits. Variable costs - things that change depending on how busy you are, like electricity, stock, or wages.

positiveMessage.title: Cost Aware!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You understand the different costs involved in running your business.

recommendation.title: Understand Your Costs
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Get to know your costs better so you can plan ahead, set prices that work, and avoid surprises. Understanding your cost structure helps you make smarter decisions and keep your business on track. You can find ways to reduce your costs, increase your profits and keep your business running.

Learn about creating a budget.

Find financial tools and templates.

questions.label: Do you monitor whether increased sales are actually leading to increased profit?
questions.helpText: Sometimes sales go up, but profit goes down, often due to rising costs, discounts, or inefficiencies.

positiveMessage.title: Profit Focused!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You track both sales and profit to understand how your pricing and costs affect your bottom line.

recommendation.title: Monitor Profitability
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: If your sales are growing but your profit is not, it is time to dig into your numbers. Review your pricing, cost structure, and operational efficiency to make sure your business is profitable, not just busy.

Learn about managing cash flow.

Access financial tools and templates.

questions.label: Do you know your break-even point?
questions.helpText: Your break-even point is when your sales cover all your costs, so you are not losing money, but you are not making a profit yet either. Knowing this helps you set goals, price your products or services properly, and plan for growth.

positiveMessage.title: Know Your Numbers!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You know how much you need to sell to cover your costs.

recommendation.title: Calculate Break-Even
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Learn how to work out your break-even point. It is a key number for your business. Even if you are making lots of sales, you could still be losing money if your costs are too high. Knowing your break-even point helps you: Set the right prices, Decide if you can afford to offer discounts, See how much profit you're really making. The more you sell above your break-even point, the stronger your business is likely to be.

Access financial planning resources.

Learn about developing a pricing strategy.

questions.label: Do you know what affects your sales?
questions.helpText: Your sales can go up or down depending on things like: Who your customers are and how many you have, How much it costs to get your supplies, especially in remote or regional areas, How you promote your business (on your own or through others), Other things outside your control, like the weather, local events, or changes in the economy.

positiveMessage.title: Sales Savvy!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strengths: You have a good understanding of what affects your sales.

recommendation.title: Understand Sales Drivers
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Learn more about what's affecting your sales and how to keep track of changes. By keeping an eye on things like customer demand, supply costs, and local trends, you'll be better prepared to adjust your products, services, or marketing when things shift.

Learn more about marketing and sales.

Find marketing and customer engagement templates.

questions.label: Do you know about any grants, incentives or support programs that could help your business?
questions.helpText: There are programs out there that can support your business. Some are from the NT Government, others from the Australian Government or local councils. They might help with things like: Growing your business (e.g. building or upgrading equipment), Hiring staff (e.g. wage subsidies or training support), Managing costs (e.g. tax breaks or energy efficiency programs).

positiveMessage.title: Support Aware!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You are aware of the support available and how to make the most of it.

recommendation.title: Explore Support Programs
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Explore what grants, incentives or programs might be available to help your business grow or save money. Even small programs can make a big difference, especially in regional or remote areas.

Access the NT Grants Portal.

Access the Australian Government Grant and Program finder.

Learn about skilling your NT workforce.

questions.label: Do you have access to enough money to support your business when you need it?
questions.helpText: Whether you are starting out, growing, or going through a slow patch, having access to funding is important. This could include: Loans or credit (debt funding), Investors or partners (equity funding), Other ways to raise money when needed. Understanding how to get funding and when to use it, can help you reach your goals and keep your business running smoothly.

positiveMessage.title: Funding Ready!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You have access or know how to access the funds your business needs to grow or stay steady.

recommendation.title: Understand Funding Options
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Learn the basics of raising funds so you are ready when your business needs a boost. Knowing your options, like loans, grants, or investors, can help you make smart choices and avoid cash flow stress.

Learn about business funding.

questions.label: Do you have systems in place to keep track of your business's money and performance?
questions.helpText: Good financial controls help you stay on top of your business. This includes: Keeping your records up to date, Tracking sales and costs against your budget, Managing debt and chasing unpaid invoices, Having a smooth invoicing process, Keeping an eye on cash flow, Understanding what drives your costs, Setting the right prices for your products or services.

positiveMessage.title: Systems in Place!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You have got solid systems in place to manage your money and track how your business is doing.

recommendation.title: Set Up Financial Systems
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Put simple financial systems in place to help you stay organised, make better decisions, and avoid cash flow problems. Even small changes, like improving invoicing or tracking costs, can make a big difference. This will also help make sure your records are true and current so you can run your business effectively.

Learn how to set up your finances.

Learn about record keeping.

Learn key financial terms.

questions.label: Does your business have enough money set aside to meet tax, super, and other legal obligations?
questions.helpText: It is important to keep money aside for things like: GST, PAYG (Pay As You Go tax), Workers' compensation, Income tax, Superannuation for your staff. You also need to make sure you have fair and legal staff contracts in place (if you employ people). Staying on top of these helps you avoid fines and keeps your business running smoothly.

positiveMessage.title: Compliance Ready!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You have planned ahead and have the funds ready to meet your legal and financial obligations.

recommendation.title: Plan for Obligations
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Make sure you understand what your business needs to pay and when. Setting aside money regularly for tax, super, and other costs helps you stay compliant and avoid last-minute stress. You can set up different bank accounts to easily keep track of these buckets of money.

Learn more about your tax obligations.

Learn about all the stages of managing employees.

questions.label: Have you thought about changing how your business works to cut costs or attract more customers?
questions.helpText: Sometimes small changes to your business model can make a big difference. You could: Add new services or experiences, Team up with other businesses to offer packages, Try new suppliers to save money, Look into new markets or customer groups. Being flexible and open to change can help your business grow and stay competitive.

positiveMessage.title: Adaptive Mindset!
positiveMessage.body: Your Strength: You are open to new ideas and willing to adapt your business to improve results.

recommendation.title: Review Business Model
recommendation.body:
Opportunity to Improve: Explore ways to change or update your business model, whether it is offering something new, teaming up with others, or finding better suppliers. Even small changes can help reduce costs or boost demand.

Learn about how you might grow your business.

conclusion.body:
Well done in completing this financial management questionnaire.

Download or save your results. Implementing small changes consistently will help you create a sustainable business practice!
